‚ÄúYou‚Äôre too old to be on here!‚Äù 

This was the first negative comment I‚Äôve ever received on Instagram and I‚Äôve been on it for several years. The man saying it appeared to be near my age, which is even stranger. 

Friends, we are NEVER too old to try new things, or to leave an imprint! We are never too old to do what we love and in this case, to connect with other people from around the globe. 

If anyone is attempting to control your presence, or trying to deny you of your joy, I hope you‚Äôll take advice from this 80 year old. YOU are here for a reason, so shine, my friend, shine!

Available $60 (PLUS shipping)Lovely pair of antique silver plate grape  scissors are 6.5". The history of these scissors is so amusing. Victorians or other proper aristocrats and such would display large clusters of grapes as a centerpiece of their dessert buffet, often using a certain type of stand. The proper etiquette for handling food was that the guest would not touch the food with their fingers, hence a proper pair of grape shears could reach into the bunch, cut the stem and extract the cluster. A guide to etiquette published in 1879, called, The Manners and Tone of Good Society, instructed, "When eating grapes, the half closed hand should be placed to the lips and the stones and skins adroitly allowed to fall into the fingers and quickly placed on the side of the plate, the back of the hand concealing the manoeuvre from view." ‚Å†

INTEGRITY & LEGACY

The society is built on legacies and legacy is not limited to money and properties; virtues, character and more are legacies man pass on. What you pass on to your next generation and people within your range of influence all start from what and who you are.

What about deciding to help build a better "air space" in the world?

You may not be raised with the best virtues but you can yet seek knowledge, renew your mind and live a better life and continue to grow in that path and when that is set we are assured that you'll raise better men. 
(Note: that is the reason being present in raising your children can not be overemphasized. Also ensure that only the right people have access to them and above all PRAY your children grow in the best way.)

How do I get better Kemi? 

*START (Receive JESUS by believing in all He did to save man) with Jesus and continue with Him...

..._to be continued_

#legacies #betteryourself
#betterlife #betterlifestyle #graciousliving #graciouslivingstyle #integrity

This platter featured here is the show stopper for this Friday‚Äôs Valentine's Day sale!  It is a large antique ironstone Davenport transfer ware platter or charger.  It was made in the 1800's. It is very rare, I actually can't find anything like it.  There is one on 1st Dibs that is a Davenport pink willow pattern for $1200! (Mine will be a fraction of that price!) 
Davenport Pottery was an English earthenware and porcelain manufacturer based in Staffordshire England and run by the Davenport family, between 1794 and 1887.  Antique transfer ware was made beginning in the 18th century in England by applying an engraved copper and inked pattern to the porcelain and then glazing and firing the piece.  Wedgewood and Staffordshire made most of the beautiful pieces.  The potteries began copying the Chinese decorated plates and products and then adapted them to European scenes instead.  Eventually the English made china and pottery featuring American scenes to ship to the new country. ‚Å£

Available $125 (PLUS  shipping). Rare opportunity to see an antique serving set in its original box.  This gorgeous fish serving set has brilliantly etched leaf decoration on the silver plate blades with sterling collars and bone handles.  Each sits in the original silk lined presentation box which has a  whimsical quote from King Lear at the top," To eat no Fish: What art thou?" Made by G B and Co. Silver in England in the 1800's.  Knife is 11.5". The box is worn.  Handle has a hairline crack. ‚Å†
*****This piece is part of the specially attained Philadelphia Main Line estate collection. These dramatic heirloom pieces are very high quality plated silver from the 1800's to early 1900's. These items are prized for their antique craftsmanship, uniqueness and history.  Some pieces have some kind of tarnish that can use more polishing than I have given, some pieces can't be polished any further.

Heritage Dunes North is a brand-new legacy community of nine exclusive homes developed by Bella Mare Real Estate Holdings, LLC, located in the enclave of beautiful Seagrove Beach, Florida, on the Gulf of Mexico. 

Bella Mare Real Estate Holdings is a real estate development firm founded by Carl and Tamara Tricoli in 2020. Tamara spent a number of years in commercial real estate and is a past board member of the Rosemary Beach Foundation. Carl is a founder and managing partner of Den-ham Capital Management LP, a global energy and resources private equity firm that has raised eleven institutional funds totaling $9 billion in committed capital with offices in Houston, Boston, London, Toronto, and Perth. The firm implements an investment philosophy that promotes responsible environmental stewardship and socially responsible development of large projects around the world‚Äîa philosophy that the Tricolis carried into their new development firm and its first community development project, Heritage Dunes. Carl and Tamara reside in Seagrove Beach and Carl also serves as chairman-elect on the Seaside Institute Board of Governors.

VULNERABLE POST‚ú®‚ú®‚ú®

My beloved and I have decided to walk away from our current living situation.  We have decided to do the next leg of our journey this way‚Ä¶ please don‚Äôt feel badly ‚Ä¶ we are staying in our conscious place while moving through this transition‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs not for lower vibrational frequencies to be able to navigate a conscious separation.

Being open and willing to do the work is a choice to love ourselves more ‚Äî first and fully.  This also comes with choosing to be open to better health, more conscious love and a willingness to do what we need to grow into being our best‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs ongoing‚Ä¶.infinite‚Ä¶ and worth while. 

Don‚Äôt give up on yourself.  We are all worthy of the highest quality of relationship with ourselves and with others‚Ä¶. And we also need to let go of what isn‚Äôt wanting to be in alignment with our highest, to be released in love. ‚Äî True love is unconditional.  To let it go is also heart centred and in our highest good too‚Ä¶ true love is not entangled.  It is free‚Ä¶

It doesn‚Äôt have to be complicated when we actually live in our hearts vs our minds.  We don‚Äôt have to make sense of anything when we live in our intuition and in our hearts. ‚ô•Ô∏è‚ú®‚ú®‚ú® 

We can suffer or stay in truth‚Ä¶ which is LOVE.  It is my intention to stay in this awareness in all relationships ‚Äî and peace will be the outcome to any circumstances. ‚ú®‚ú®üôèüèª

Letting go in love.  I love you dearly dearest.. and I wish you the most glorious, blessed, abundant journey ahead.  Thank you for all you brought, gave, taught and shared with me.  You‚Äôre forever in my heart and a part of my soul.  It‚Äôs not easy ‚Äî üíî but every time my heart breaks it expands and grows bigger upon healing ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π ‚ù§Ô∏è. 

In grace, love and gratitude. ‚ú®‚ú®‚ú®‚ú®‚ú®‚ù§Ô∏è

Originally, I though this piece was a pitcher for iced beverages, but upon more reading, I realized it was a claret jug! Claret (or red Bordeaux wine) originally needed to be decanted to have time to breathe before consumption. Additionally, elaborate dinners (and the accompanying dishes) were part of the well-bred Victorian‚Äôs life. 

Early claret jugs were glass or solid silver. In the 19th century, hinged lids, handles and more elaborate designs came into fashion. Based on the handle and design elements, I believe this piece is from the turn of the century. WWI, rising costs and fashion ended the production of claret jugs in the 1920‚Äôs. Wine fell out of fashion following WWI, in part due to thousands of vines across Europe being damaged during the bombings of WWI and WII. 

When wine‚Äôs popularity returned in the 1970‚Äôs, the fashion was to serve it from the bottle, so claret jugs did not enjoy a reemergence as a serving vessel. 

This would make a lovely gift for the wine connesieur in your life, or up your game on your water-drinking habit by filling it with cut citrus or berries for an infused water carafe.

Did you know about claret jugs? Answer below with a ü•≥ or üòØ emoji!

The sun is happily shining today‚Ä¶such a lovely sight and quite mild out considering it‚Äôs been in the 20‚Äôs. 

A little background on this Victorian sofa.  We found this in an antique shop over 20 years ago.  We think it‚Äôs late 1800‚Äôs - early 1900‚Äôs. Since our home has a Victorian facade we thought, why not decorate in Victorianüò≥. Anyway, that didn‚Äôt last long. 

Victorian Period in furniture dates from approximately 1830-1890. The reign of Queen Victoria (1837-1901) and her love of the ornate greatly affected design styles during this period. Most Victorian furniture is a mixture of many other styles including Gothic, Tudor, Elizabethan, Rococo, and Neoclassic, with Gothic and Rococo being the most common. True Victorian furniture is difficult to recognize because of this mixing of styles‚Ä¶it was also hand made.  The Victorian look was typically cluttered with dark furniture, heavy fabrics, and lots of china.  After the late 1890‚Äôs most Victorian furniture started to be mass produced. 

My living room is a combination of Victorian, 50‚Äôs, a Persian rug, vintage finds, a Home Goods table and FB Marketplace mirror.  This is definitely what you would ‚Äúa collected room‚Äù.

Have a Happy Friday‚ô•Ô∏è

George V English Sterling Serving Tray crafted by silversmith by J.B. Chatterley & Sons of Birmingham. It was made in 1929. It has beautifully hand armorial crest in the center reading "FOI ROI DROIT" (translates Faith, King, Right) with the unicorn and lion, the symbols of Great Britain. This rare silver tray measures 17 1/4 inches by 21 3/4 inches and has a handsome gadroon and shell border.
.

Spent most of the day at home working on one thing or another.  Yesterday I finished renovating my office room and put this in a corner near my desk chair. Today I poked at it for a moment and tears welled up in my eyes. I‚Äôm a very sensitive soul that had only become more sensitive during the pandemic.  It has felt like love and compassion have often been left behind in favor of the ego and whose right and whose wrong.  I bought this at a fair just before the pandemic hit and it has been a loving message to return to over the pest couple of years.  #nevergiveup #bekind #stayopenhearted  We are more similar than we are different. The ego wants to say otherwise but I do not believe that. At the heart, at the core #weareallone No one is right or wrong. Difference and diversity is beautiful not threatening.  In time hopefully we will collectively see that more. Until then I practice #lovigkindnessmeditation and# compassion for myself and others. #peaceful #lovingheart #breathe #belonging #community #mindfulness #dalilama #graciousliving

Gracious is my word of the year. It means to favor, to show kindness, and to be compassionate. It is a character trait of a loving God. My focus verse: "The Lord is gracious and compassionate, slow to anger and rich in love." Psalms 145:8 NIV
.
My aim is to focus on God's graciousness so I may fall more in love with Him. My secondary goal is to allow God's graciousness to work through me that I may deal with others the way He has so graciously dealt with me.
.
Do you have a word that defines your goal for the year? Please share. I'd love to pray for you.‚ù§

Dirilyte, as it is known today, was originally created as Dirigold. Dirilyte is a romantic product with an international flavor. The alloy from which our product is produced was originally developed in Sweden in 1914. The creator of this solid bronze alloy was a Swedish metallurgist by the name of CarI Molin. He created the beautiful items in Dirigold and brought them to the World's Fair in New York City. It was met with great acclaim and after some time it was decided to manufacture the new golden-hued flatware and holloware in the United States. A building was secured in Kokomo, Indiana where the manufacturing organization was moved. This operation was under the supervision of Mr. Molin. He brought six men and their families with him from Sweden and from this beginning others were trained and the plant enlarged. 
.
In 1935 the Federal Trade Commision brought suit against the company, charging that the name "Dirigold" was misleading to the public because the alloy did not contain any gold. As a result, the company was forced to change the product nurme. It was decided to change the corporate name as well as the product name, the new name coined was DIRILYTE. The company stopped producing in 1986. (History from the Dirilyte website.)
.

IN HONOR OF WINTER SOLSTICE
‚Ä¢
On this shortest day of sunlight of the year, I find myself wishing our culture celebrated the gifts of nature a little bit more. There is a beautiful meme going around the gardening accounts right now that talks about normalizing gift giving in a way that promotes nature and honors living a more purposeful and reflective lifestyle.
‚Ä¢
It's this slower lifestyle that I've been working on embracing since founding Heirloom Potager that I am craving the most. A lifestyle that doesn't pull in so many directions, but rather one that sets the pace of the day to match both the essence of the season.
‚Ä¢
On this longest evening of the year, I can't help but hold my mug of hot chocolate and wonder: what if we listened to nature more and tried to contort it less?
‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢

Happy Tuesday! I should have added this yesterday, but better late than never. I originally wanted to post this as a video,  but it did not work out. 

I actually had a point that I wanted to stress with this post, and it is to shop your home first. I was itching to add something different to my dining room table and instead of running out and buying something new, I moved my favorite faux floral arrangement from our master bathroom (which I purchased a year ago @knickknacks_tx ) and paired it with a cachepot that is part of my blue and white collection that is displayed on my living room console and WALAH! I have a new edition to my dining room table. Remember: Restyle. Reuse. Repurpose.

Brace yourself... Here's a #TablescapeTuesday Christmas feast for the eyes!!!

If one can even get past the gold embroidered linens that once graced Princess Grace's table... This is just a little taste of the delightfully unending, curated opulence of Ginger and James Hyland's "Jeweled Christmas" at The Towers in Natchez! Every square inch of their historic home is draped in antique and vintage costume jewelry for the holiday season, some scored from movies you know and love! There's even a crown room!!!! Swipe to see just one of the dozens of decked out trees...

And of course Ginger prefers shimmering glass and crystal to porcelain, the sparkle! The dining table is set with ruby red McKee Rock Crystal from the early 1900s, including this rare set of 8 plates - in her decades of searching and collecting, she's only found eight! Let's help her out and keep our eyes peeled for more!

Ôº≠Ôº©ÔºÆÔº§Ôº¶ÔºµÔº¨ ÔºßÔº©Ôº∂Ôº©ÔºÆÔºß. If your gift comes with strings attached, then you're not giving a gift. You're making a contract. If there are conditions that you put upon the item you are giving - such as expecting them to wear your gift often, or publicly thank you on social media, to give in return, or not re-gift - then that is not a freely given offering. There is an emotional attachment connected.

That's not to say that emotions shouldn't be attached to gifts. Actually, the best kind of gifts come with emotions attached. But instead of connecting emotionally to WHAT you are giving - you must be mindful to connect to the PERSON that you are giving to.

Think about the recipient, their heart, their spirit, and all the things that surround them. Imbue that gift with kind thoughts, energy, and love.

But most importantly, expect nothing in return. If you always expect your giving to be reciprocated, it makes it impossible to give freely. In turn, that makes it hard for you to ever truly receive from others. Subconsciously, you have created the idea that no one gives without a catch.

So keep in mind, if your love language is gifts - make sure you are intentional in how you are giving. And remember that the most important gifts are priceless.

When I am asked why am I contented, I say because I fully embrace anything that is to come my way. 
I say, I‚Äôm happy not because I never had challenges. Actually I did, ton of them that made me cringe, cry, and even scream, but life is all about losses and wins. I‚Äôve also had moments of laughter and disappointments!
However, having faith I‚Äôd say is my anchor to handling the unpredictable discoveries in life, and placing my trust in the Lord, for Him, everything is possible. 
Above all, I‚Äôm proud of the woman I have become, and what I‚Äôve achieved. 

For that I‚Äôm grateful.

‚Ä¢
Sometimes artists create in a flurry.  Other times there is much to consider and work through with loads of discussion.  Creative struggle can be beautiful while at hand Interior Design can be approached as a business ‚Ä¶ formulaic ‚Ä¶ fast ‚Ä¶ deadline driven as a rule.  With luck the designer has the chance to ruminate on a space alongside the client over time.  Such is this.  We are still in process.  It is a different sort of room in use ‚Ä¶ a large sitting room wet bar.  Salon?  First was the construction portion with cabinetry and plumbing, mirrors, hardware, and layers of lighting.  Client antiques.  Custom settee.  Modern flourishes and added crusty old things.  Which then had dust and crust removed.  Accessories.  Last bit will be rug and window treatments.  Still chewing while we all evolve.
.
.
.

Contrary to popular belief, working with clients‚Äô items can be a grand adventure.  We opened the container and started by sorting the keepers on the warehouse loading dock.  The move of items came from Buckhead, which has a completely different feel so some reinvention was needed.  From there we could identify that new seating was required but in this space, not much was added beyond the upholstered pieces and a modern art original (not shown). Oh and the ceiling tinted pink was a must ‚Ä¶ everyone looks fantastic in this space, especially at night.  Her antiques set the tone.

Sometimes artists create in a flurry.  Other times there is much to consider and work through with loads of discussion.  Creative struggle can be beautiful while at hand Interior Design can be approached as a business ‚Ä¶ formulaic ‚Ä¶ fast ‚Ä¶ deadline driven as a rule.  With luck the designer has the chance to ruminate on a space alongside the client over time.  Such is this.  We are still in process.  It is a different sort of room in use ‚Ä¶ a large sitting room wet bar.  Salon?  First was the construction portion with cabinetry and plumbing, mirrors, hardware, and layers of lighting.  Client antiques.  Custom settee.  Modern flourishes and added crusty old things.  Which then had dust and crust removed.  Accessories.  Last bit will be rug and window treatments.  Still chewing while we all evolve.
.
.
.

Can‚Äôt wait to try this festive holiday cocktail - Run Rum Rudolph! ‚ù§Ô∏èüçπ

2 c fresh cranberries¬†
1/2 c sugar
2 c water
1 c white rum
1/2 c fresh lime juice
1/4 c fresh orange juice
Rosemary for garnish
¬†
Combine water, cranberries & sugar together & bring to a boil to dissolve sugar & create a simple syrup. Remove mixture from  heat & let it cool completely. Strain cranberries from mixture & pour into a pitcher. Add rum, lime & orange juice. To serve, pour over ice and garnish.

It‚Äôs beginning to look a lot like cocktails! This festive Bellini is always a üåü at our holiday gatherings! Cheers!

üåü1 bag 12 oz. fresh cranberries
üåü1 c water
üåü2 tbsp chopped fresh rosemary
üåü1/2 c coconut sugar
üåü1 1/2 c orange juice
üåüProsecco

Simple Syrup Directions:
Cook cranberries in water over medium heat until pop open. Remove pan from heat. Add coconut sugar & rosemary. Cover mixture & allow to cool completely. Press mixture through a cheesecloth or small strainer to remove juice. Place the simple syrup in a bottle & discard the rest.

In a fluted glass add 1 tbsp simple syrup, ¬º c orange juice & 5 oz of Prosecco. Store any remaining simple syrup in the refrigerator for 5 days.

Forget traditional wrapping paper - use something that will last! We ‚ù§Ô∏è wrapping homemade gifts with our guest towels. This is my go-to easy recipe for Slice & Bake Spicy Cheese Wafers - it‚Äôs a crowd favorite!

¬Ω	cup unsalted butter, room temp
2 c grated sharp cheddar (grate this yourself!)
¬º	tsp cayenne pepper
1¬Ω c flour
¬Ω	tsp salt

In a food processor, pulse the butter, cheddar & cayenne until smooth. Add the flour and salt and pulse until mixture is crumbly. Continue to mix until the dough forms large clumps - but not a single ball.

Mold the dough on plastic wrap in a rough log shape - about 12 inches long and 1-2 inches in diameter. Tightly wrap the dough in plastic wrap so it‚Äôs covered tightly. Refrigerate overnight. Preheat oven to 350. Slice into 1/4 in slices, place on a cookie sheet lined with parchment paper. Bake at 350 for about 20 minutes.

Good morning! Enjoying the morning light and putting the finishing touches of Christmas decorations up! I heard that some people do a different theme each year, but I always put the same decorations up and add a few new pieces each year. This year, I‚Äôll be adding lots of new-to-me vintage ornaments to my Christmas tree. My window wreaths are from hobby lobby a few years ago and I just got glue the ribbon to the top of my window and pull it off at the end of the season - no one is the wiser! I like to look at high-end stores for ideas and sometimes purchase a few pieces, but then go to hobby lobby for things I can try to find that fit my budget better like greenery and ribbon. Monday morning Blue Willow for you my friends. 

You may have seen the secretary where I store and display much of my Blue Willow pieces. I spent a little time yesterday adding some fresh Christmas greenery, Paper Whites, a mini herb planter (in the champagne bucket) and Ilex  berries all from @traderjoes. I also added a few faux lemons that were part of a potpourri  bag from @homegoods because I love the pop of yellow with the red and blue. The smell of the citrus and the greenery is so nice. 
I also added wreaths from @homedepot to the inside of the secretary doors. It stays open and they fit there perfectly. 

A little touch of Christmas and my secretary is ready for the season. Taking everyday pieces and adding just a bit of Christmas to them is my favorite way to decorate my home for the season. 

How about you?

A day in food and culinary heaven with a deep connection with nature at @new.earth.school It‚Äôs home to prominent food creations like @zestubud and @usadabali 

I love their philosophy of growing, cooking, healing - preparing food in harmony with the Earth through various innovative and incredibly delicious ways. 

Part of the day included walking barefoot through the rice fields heading to their 4-hectare food forest, where we foraged for ingredients we would bring back for lunch. Iwan passionately shared stories along the way and enlightened us on the various food that they were growing in the garden. Chef @made.masak ‚Äòs electrifying energy was palpable as she and the ‚Äúkitchen angels‚Äù prepared the incredible plant based feast for us to enjoy, fresh produce that were all from the garden or food forest. 

If anyone‚Äôs looking for a unique experience, join them for a day, a week, or even a month of internship. You‚Äôll certainly come away more than just learning about the food we put on our plates üíö

3. Replace your traditional door with a pocket door.‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
4. Use high-gloss paint to reflect light and amplify the space.‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
5. Optimize storage space with built-in shelving to increase floor space.‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä

Happy Sunday!!!!! May your Sunday be filled with simple joys, peaceful moments, and lots of love ‚ù§Ô∏è I am thankful I was able to be a comfort to our grandson yesterday.  We soaked in every minute of this funny , full of joy baby. #GraciousLiving #SundayBlessings

‚ô•Ô∏èMake Everyday Sweet‚ô•Ô∏è

Last night was just so wonderful that I want to relive it all again. 

Jim and I started dating very young, him going to LaSalle College High School and I went to the sister school,  St Basil Academy.  Our friends since 1977 (he‚Äô78 and me ‚Äò79) joined us for a buffet dinner, with  appreciation and celebration of our friendship of 4 decades.  What a blessing. 

We made two entree choices of Jambalaya and Roast Beef sandwiches, the easy recipe calling for cooking the beef overnight in the crockpot.  This meal was divine,  so festive and delicious.  It melted in your mouth, as my Dear Mother would say. 

We reminisced and talked about football, basketball and cheerleading days, classes and antics that we all participated in.  Summers at the shore and winter trips  to the mountains . We shared about our families, parents, loss and all the wonderful moments that made our hearts seemingly,  skip a beat.  Laughing, crying, being in the moment.  And Again no pictures. 

I wanted to share however, this  Sweets Tier of homemade treats prepared for our evening.  Filled  with chocolate chip cookies, Heath bar crunch, chocolate covered pretzels and Peppermint Bark.  My most requested treats at the holidays and some gifts brought by our friends last night.  The Holly looks so beautiful in the cranberry filled vase along with the sweet message on the hand towel to Make Everyday Sweet. 

Basking in the afterglow of love transcending through the years and feeling so thankful to see our dear friends once again.  Now this is truly a blessing. 

Happy Sunday Sweet Friends ! 

Love, 
Marialyce XO

I‚Äôve always had a love for plants and its healing properties üíö This weekend I got to immerse even deeper at @sarideviecolodge learning about wild tropical medicinal plants in particular to boost immunity and supporting liver health. 

The beautiful and tranquil setting of the Batukaru mountain range and rice fields were the perfect backdrop for our workshop. Yasmine has such an extensive wealth of knowledge to share I honestly think we didn‚Äôt even scratch the surface. She was like a walking encyclopaedia of medicinal plants - sharing amazing insights of sambiloto, meniran, brotowali, sembung, mugwort, papaya leaf, turmeric, and many others. We also went off on a rice field walk and garden tour learning more about other plants and their medicinal uses... plucking away at the various plants and chewing their leaves, amid the bitterness, to which I learned is the most important taste to humans. 

Here‚Äôs another fascinating thing I learned. If we put fresh mushrooms with the gills facing upwards under the sun for just 30 minutes, it helps us to take in more Vitamin D3! (Next time you‚Äôll see me sunbathing next to trays of mushrooms in my garden!)

The owner of the lodge also lovingly cooked us a delicious vegan lunch with fresh ingredients found from their garden. Surrounded by so much nature and the mountain air, I had my best sleep in months! Highly recommend to stay at their lodge where they will welcome you like family. 

If anyone in Bali is keen to join these medicinal plant workshops, PM me and I will put you in touch with the organizers. 

Here‚Äôs an interesting article to share about the list of over 130 drugs that are actually made from plants! üå± 
https://www.thoughtco.com/drugs-and-medicine-made-from-plants-608413

My one and only Thanksgiving picture from yesterday üòÇ This is the biggest carrot I‚Äôve ever peeled. I always peel extra because my daughter will eat them about as fast as I can peel them, same goes for boiled eggs but hey I‚Äôm not complaining other than I almost ran out of eggs üò≥
‚ÄúEven If‚Äù I remind myself to say when immediately faced with change or inconvenience as opposed to my usual ‚ÄúWhat If‚Äù. 
It would have been okay‚Ä¶ I didn‚Äôt finish a couple dishes and a few chores went undone, but the time spent rushing through my tasks were for the first time smoother and more in tune with my husband than ever before. He only had to tell me to breath twice üòÇ The kind of days I get an ‚ÄúI love you‚Äù out of nowhere. Those days are my favorite. We both enjoy cooking and entertaining family and friends. In our trailer, we could never be in the kitchen together‚Ä¶. It was chaos and constantly running into each other and needing the sink at the same time üòÖ Now, we still need the sink at the same time but now I happily step aside with patience, before grace, I could easily let out a nice big huff and complain or have a less than pleasant look on my face. How attractive ü§¢
Yesterday was not perfect but full of so much love and I feel overly gracious for God‚Äôs blessings in our lives and the ones that are in store‚ù§Ô∏è
.
.
.

If Thanksgiving is the one holiday that is purely American, then Ralph Lauren is our purely American designer. In the 2017 Architectural Digest article about the Lauren‚Äôs Bedford, New York, house, Stephen Drucker wrote the following:
‚†Ä
‚ÄúTo fully appreciate it you must try not to think about the store windows and displays you know so well. This is not a stage; it is not about selling; this is where Ricky and Ralph Lauren have lived for 13 years and where they have raised three children. It is their home, and in the realm of interior design it is very much an original. There is no need to search for social meaning in it, as often happens when the subject turns to Ralph Lauren. Quite simply, it is English in flavor but with an American energy, and whether Nancy Mitford would approve or not is irrelevant. By now we should all understand that this is an interpretation of Englishness, not a recreation of it.‚Äù
‚†Ä
Love that description! üß°üß°üß°

You serve the best by doing what you love the most.üíó

Loving what you do is a wonderful thing. 
Oftentimes, it‚Äôs not¬†just¬†the work that we love, it‚Äôs the reward and satisfaction we get after doing it well. And we all know that getting things done well involves exerting effort as well as the occasional¬†late night or two...or three. It‚Äôs a habitual cycle.üôà

‚è∞ I'm certainly guilty of not clocking in the extended hours. I enjoy what I do to a point where I become obsessed with seeing the creative process through to the end result , so I can reach that dopamine level of high....feeling fulfilled, accomplished, and satisfied each time I achieve a project completion.

Loving what you do might not feel like a job anymore but it still requires hard work. It‚Äôs pretty much human nature to enjoy the things we're good at, but in order to be good at it, we still need to put in some serious elbow grease.

So to all my dear friends, family, Entrepreneurs, and business folk.... I see you smiling, I see your heart jump at every opportunity to do what you love, but I also know what it took to realise your dreams,  and accomplish the work you love. 

Wishing you success and blessings ‚≠ê

As the demand for commercially produced biscuits (or cookies) grew in the 19th century, the need for proper storage increased as well. Biscuit tins (barrels) became more grandiose during the Victorian era, as did much silverware, especially pieces which adorned the dinner table. The advent of afternoon tea also increased both the need and the desire for highly decorative biscuit boxes, which would be required to be aesthetically pleasing to take pride of place alongside tea and coffee services.
.
I have such fond memories of Omi, my Charleston grandmother always having Benne wafers or cheese straws available in her beautiful English English Silver biscuit. I like to use them for floral centerpieces as well!! 
.

It‚Äôs okay to choose what‚Äôs easy.

I think many of us subconsiously believe that whatever is most challenging is somehow the best or necessary.
*If it‚Äôs not challenging, somehow it‚Äôs not worth it. 
*If I‚Äôm not constantly exhausted, I‚Äôm not doing it right. 
‚û°Ô∏èWe‚Äôre drowning in our own endless pursuit of productivity and challenge.

Truth be told, there are things in life that are going to be challenging (and even more than that). It‚Äôs the unavoidable truth of the human experience, SO when I can choose a gentle, easy approach, why wouldn‚Äôt I?

Some ways I have made things easy:
‚û°Ô∏èOwning less stuff means I have less stuff to organize and keep track of. It also means less clean up. 
‚û°Ô∏èI do not adopt any complicated systems. I just use my notes app, an e-calendar, and my phone alarm. I try to take a similar approach with my business. 
‚û°Ô∏èI have a limited wardrobe with pieces that coordinate well with each other. It‚Äôs super easy. I no longer stand indecisively in my closet  debating what to wear and feeling like I ‚Äòhave nothing.‚Äô 
‚û°Ô∏èMuch of what I do through the holiday season is what feels joyful and easy. I make the same holiday meal every year, I stick with a simple list for gifts, go with light decor and I say no to many things. I also hold a gentle routine through the month of December. 

What are some ways you are embracing ‚Äòeasy‚Äô?
What is one way you could embrace ‚Äòeasy‚Äô?

Instantly recognizable by this shard found by my grandson in the Russian River, Blue Willow dinnerware has been around for centuries. A favorite of both high brow folks, William Randolph Hearst had a gold rimmed version at his California castle-San Simeon, and more humble folks, Aunt Bea of Mayberry had this pattern in her kitchen‚ù§Ô∏è It‚Äôs beloved for a reason.  I love it‚Äôs vibrant blue color, even though it does have many different color versions, and the romantic story often associated with it. Maybe it‚Äôs time to add some to your collection?

Taking some time tonight to reflect on every moment that makes this life special‚Ä¶ whether it be a beautiful waterfall, foraging with my Papa O‚Äô or snuggling on the couch watching Hallmark movies with the hubby (and Emmylou of course üê±). Last week at church our pastor talked about being thankful in our prayers instead of going to God asking for all the things we think we need Him to fix/do/give us. Because let‚Äôs be honest‚Ä¶ He already knows! Instead I was challenged to go to God with thanks for all that He has already blessed me with and for always being there for me. Life isn‚Äôt always a Hallmark movie‚Ä¶ (piles of laundry swallowing our closet alive, half finished landscaping, working nights and trying to maintain healthy relationships‚Ä¶) Despite circumstances there is always something to be thankful for, sometimes it just takes a different perspective

This set of four D & C (Delinieres and Cie)., L. Bernardaud & Co. Limoges, France fine porcelain dinner plates are simply stunning. 
The lip of each piece is encircled with a distinctive flowering papyrus that is still found on Bernardaud dinnerware today, while the rim is bordered with a gold Greek key pattern. 
Heavy, brilliant craftsmanship that you can feel, with very little wear to the gold. Absolutely no chips or cracks. 
Measuring 10 1/8‚Äù 
The mark in the back dates each piece between 1894-1900.

Whole lotta‚Äô unpacking going on! My grandmother used to own a treasure of a shop called ‚ÄúThe Chambered Nautilus‚Äù that sold fine china & crystal & every imaginable beautiful thing. ‚ú®

As I was carefully packing for our move, the perfume of packing peanuts took me right back to being a little girl & spending summers in her store‚Ä¶I loved running to the shop doors to have her greet us with a big hug - telling us about all the delicious things she‚Äôd prepared for us to eat.

The gracious way she treated every guest in her shop AND in her home will always be the way we treat our guestsüíï.

Building a new life is exciting. Treasuring the one that got us here is equally soulful. 

Also: Cliff still fits in his varsity wrestling letterman jacket. #hesallmineladies ‚ù§Ô∏è

Today we created a living inspiration board for Holiday 2021. We prepped by spending this week gathering inspiration from our Insta Friends, Pinterest, Shelter Mags and beyond. Once we decided on the color palette, we did a forage from our own collections to see what we already had. 

Pro Tips - 

‚Ä¢ Building a palette that is complimentary to your Interior Design makes everything feel intentional and look richer, but still cuts down what you need to purchase

‚Ä¢ We use our dining table scape to inform our entire holiday decorating scheme so that everything coordinates effortlessly and seamlessly

‚Ä¢ We start with natural lighter tones for Thanksgiving and then add loads of sparkle and dramatic deeper tones for Christmas and New Years

‚Ä¢ Starting planning now and add to it instead of tearing down and starting from scratch November 26 will eliminates a ton of work.

‚Ä¢ We also use this palette to inspire our gift wrapping for this year

Friday night is the perfect time to build out your table scape over a glass of wine. Hope you are inspired. Tag us so we can see your designs!

Here's a few photos of Elsie, Homer's mother, around the house in honor of Family Stories Month and National Housewives Day. 

Elsie believed life that life should be a party, and lived her life accordingly! She was not your typical housewife. I heard stories growing up about Elsie routinely making 12 (!) pies a week and setting one of them on the windowsill within arms' reach of her boys. Homer said they would cut a quarter (!) of a pie for themselves and walk down the road with their snack, feeling proud of themselves that they had "gotten away" with it again. Looking back though, Homer remarked he was sure Elsie did it on purpose‚Äîshe loved to feed her family, and to give her boys the gleeful joy of pranking their mother. 

Similarly, Elsie wasn't chained to the rigid schedule many 40's era housewives lived by...it was nothing for a child to remark that they wanted a certain cake‚Äîand Elsie would head to the kitchen to make it, even if it was 10 o'clock at night!

I am striving to find more joy in my housework this week, as I reflect on Elsie's example. What do you do to make your housework more enjoyable? Comment below!

For their SoHo residence, shoe designer @brian_atwood and his husband @drjakedeutsch called on interior designer Andre Mellone (@studiomellone) to carefully craft the interiors of the dramatic space. Mellone drew influences from famed American designer Halston, whose similarly designed double-floor house featured complimentary textures invigorated by lush bamboo plants. The living room is bathed in light thanks to floor-to-ceiling windows framed with cream-color linen curtains, an understated element that, with a Bert Stern photo of Marilyn Monroe over the fireplace, established the area‚Äôs tone.

Down Syndrome - Trisomy 21

An extra chromosome. Extra attitude. Extra personality. Just all around extra.
But this world would have you believe people with Down syndrome aren‚Äôt worth it. Like the little baby boy with Down syndrome who was denied a heart transplant because ‚Äúit would be a waste of a heart‚Äù as the Doctor stated. 

But they are. They are worth it. They are loved and they deserve a fighting chance at life. They are valued. They are HUMAN. 
October is #downsyndromeawarenessmonth . I wanted to be sure to make a post before the month ends but we celebrate Down syndrome year round. Join us!

‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢

Popcorn Snack Mix:
4 c popped popcorn
1/4 c cocktail peanuts
1/4 c mini pretzels
1/4 c candy corn
1/2 c white chocolate chips
1 tsp coconut oil

In a large bowl, stir popcorn, peanuts, pretzels & candy corn. Spread on parchment paper lined cookie sheet.
Microwave white chocolate chips & coconut oil for about 20 seconds and stir until smooth. Keep microwaving & stirring until completely melted & smooth. Drizzle over popcorn mix & allow to cool before serving.

Something about cool, fall weather makes me crave a big pot of soup & Garlic Cheddar Biscuits! 

Recipe cred @laralyncarter 

1 1/2 c almond flour
1/2 tsp garlic powder
1/2 tsp onion powder
1 tbsp baking powder
1/2 tsp fine sea salt
2 eggs
1 cup cheddar cheese
4 tbsp butter, melted
1/2 c plain greek yogurt or sour cream

Combine dry ingredients & break up any clumps in the flour. Add eggs, butter & yogurt, mixing well. Stir in cheese. Divide batter evenly between 12 muffin cups. Bake @ 425 degrees for 10 minutes.

This is the old kitchen in our 1905 farmhouse. üíõ The house is known by the older generation in our tiny upstate town as ‚ÄúThe Big House‚Äù. 

My 80 year old neighbor told me his parents met in ‚ÄúThe Big House‚Äù when they summered here in 1930.  The farmhouse is the heart and soul of our little compound. 

The cupboards, the walls tell stories‚Ä¶
The air is sweet with hickory & time. The table has dents in it from my toddler daughter banging her fork. Numerous art projects. Countless nights with so many friends laughing, and laughing, and‚Ä¶ laughing.  Epic meals. Some bad ones thrown in.  When we get to the farm, the world around us stops swirling and time turns elastic.  I want to share this small insight with you - that not everything in my world is fancy (hardly). The imperfections create memorable moments.

On the table is our everyday China from growing up in GA üí´ I found handwritten notes from my grandmother in every piece of amber I unpacked‚Ä¶

Starting a new week and a new monogram - probably my favorite chinoiserie design yet.
windows: occupied ‚úÖ the guest room gets the best light and is therefore our green gang hangout space. üåµüå±ü™¥

Monograms first appeared on coins in ancient Greece as early as 350 B.C. They were originally used to by combining the first two letters of a city with a symbol. They were then used primarily by royalty, authorities and dignitaries. 
.
As the use of monograms grew through the centuries they were used to identify items of clothing, linens and home furnishings as well as weaponry and armor.  They were a symbol of status and became the height of fashion. 
.
They also began to be used by artists and business to brand their products, such as the interlocked C‚Äôs and R‚Äôs of Coco Channel and Rolls Royce.
.
The tradition monogram is your first initial, followed by a larger letter for your last initial and your middle on the right. The tradition southern wedding monogram is the bride‚Äôs first initial on the left, with the grooms first initial on the right and the larger last initial in the middle.
.
We carry a curated selection of hand engraved silver items; you can even search by engraving our our website! (Link in bio) We are also blessed to partner with a fantastic hand engraver who can personalize your heirloom silver or your silver purchase. 
.

Welcome Carlos Gamez de Francisco!! The artist grew up in Cuba and was educated in an academic style influenced by the Russian Academy.  The artist recalls a story when his mother saved for years for a living room couch. Once obtained- it was promptly covered in plastic and sitting on it was forbidden. Now living in Kentucky his work often juxtaposes animals into highly traditional and elegant settings. Swipe to see the artist with his sweet dog sitting on his lovely couch! Hi y'all! I'm Katherine! Lots of lovely new faces around here, so I thought I would introduce myself and tell you how happy I am to see you! üëãüèªüíï

üñã Pender & Peony is now my full time business that I started back in 2014. It was only a lifestyle blog then, but 2 years ago I took it in a new direction to sell specially curated collections of vintage and antique decor, art, and chic bric-a-brac ‚Äî what I fondly refer to as classically charming curios!

ü¶ã When it comes to design I love an effortless mix of high and low...When patterns collide...Sophisticated pastels...The irresistible patina of an heirloom well loved! And firmly believe that it all doesn't have to cost an arm and a leg!

üå∏ I spent 10 years working in the art museum and auction worlds where I became a master at real life Tetras and the art of cleaning antiques! BTW I earned a master's degree in History & Museum Studies.

üéì I attended an all woman‚Äôs college, and will forever be a Randi-Mac girl!

üíö Follow along for a dose of Southern cordiality....Loads of vintage and antique curios....And decorating inspiration with creative advice!

üëáNow it's your turn to finish the introduction....

WE SAVED OUR ORIGINAL WOOD FLOORS!  as some of you might have seen from our previous plan, tile was our first choice for the bathroom floor. while we had the hardwood exposed in what used to be our closet, we assumed it had been removed from the bathroom side when contractors flipped our home a few years ago. but on demo day, we found out that wasn‚Äôt the case- they still exist, and they are gorgeous! we quickly pivoted away from our tile idea and jumped on trying to save these floors. i mean, these trees died for our sins 150+ years ago so it would be a lil rude to remove them from their final resting place, no? we can tile another bathroom floor that doesn‚Äôt look like THIS. (also, major shoutout to Hugh for achieving this himself after finding out our contractor was going to charge us an additional $1000 to refinish these floors ü•µ).

Buyers: A Tokeneke neighborhood treasure!

I have always admired this colonial house from the road, and loved touring the interiors yesterday.  It has been beautifully renovated by the homeowner, the talented interior designer @melindatweeddale who was in the decorating department of House & Garden Magazine before moving to fashion as a photo stylist for Glamour Magazine, a Fashion Editor for Elle Magazine and a Design Director for Ralph Lauren.  No wonder this was my favorite house of the week! 
Houses decorated by professional interior designers are a bonus for a buyer, as designers pay close attention to important design details, use the best quality materials, and bring out the best features in a space. Several highlights of this stunning house, like the serene blue master bathroom and the glorious gardens have been featured in @cottagesgardens 
BTW...the 8 cherry trees in front are absolutely stunning in full bloom in the Spring and the Captains quarters office at the top of the house is a special treat. So much wonderful design to enjoy!

We are here because of Him!

Getting to know God for myself as I got older has really helped me to appreciate others more. That might sound funny but it's not that I was like others don't matter, but I did have a select few that were at the top of the list. However, when seeing others through God's eyes you get to see just how special each person is and how much more so that Jesus (God's Only Son) died for them?

God not only gave His Son to set us free but He blesses us with His grace. He allows us to prosper even when we're not doing our best, even when we don't deserve it. Let that sit for a while.....

So let us be thankful to God for each other, for others because when we look at others we see the grace of God written all over. You are here today, I am here today because of what He has done for us!

Happy Wednesday! A few weeks ago, I announced a collaboration with some amazing accounts to bring you all a NEW weekly hashtag #ADwellingToRemember 

Are you a fan of beautiful interiors that are timeless and classic with a twist? Maybe a bold wallpaper, a pop of color and hopefully some vintage mixed in? Well then this hashtag is for you!

But for the next several weeks we will be highlighting the each of  hosts accounts with a little get to know you and today we feature @cjswank_newyork ~ CJ bought her 115 year old farmhouse sight unseen at an online foreclosure auction within minutes of seeing the listing. No inspections were made, and no friends or family were in the area. The house had been vandalized in the decade it sat empty, and one year later there‚Äôs still lots to be done. 
Although not a designer, CJ spent her working life in the arts, most recently as the Visual Arts Director of the State of Arizona, and was an exhibiting artist herself. Currently, she is participating in the #oneroom challenge and will be turning her guestroom into an English countryside/chinoiserie retreat. ~

üåüGRACIOUSüåü one of my favourite and under-utilised words. Merriam-Webster defines, GRACIOUS as: *marked by tact, kindness and courtesy *characterised by charm, good taste, generosity of spirit *merciful and compassionate.
Synonyms for GRACIOUS include~ CORDIAL, AFFABLE, GENIAL, SOCIABLE. GRACIOUS implies courtesy and kindly consideration. CORDIAL stresses warmth. AFFABLE implies easy approachability and readiness to respond pleasantly to conversation, requests or proposals. GENIAL stresses cheerfulness and even joviality. SOCIABLE suggests a genuine liking for the companionship of others, markedly pleasant and easy socially. 
üíüMore graciousness and less negativefulness.

Being gracious and offering compliments to people around them is not a natural skill for kids . It needs to be a social skill taught to our children .
I want them to care about the people around them as much as they care about themselves. By giving people compliments they can see how much it brightens people‚Äôs days . Teaching them to give compliments helps to build empathy . Which focuses on character, strengths and accomplishments rather than appearance. Offering simple praises makes people feel appreciated and we all deserve to feel that. 
Of course this is all easier said than done. But by teaching by example our children can develop similar praise giving skills. üíï‚ú®üíï‚ú® #compliments #graciousliving #positivevibes #teaching #empathy #teachingtoddlers #toddlerlife #mindfulness #lifteachotherup #appreciation #appreciateothers  #healthylifestyle #love #motherdaughter #encourgement #momlife #mom #momoftwo #sahm #momoftwogirls

Growing up I‚Äôd visit my grandparents farm every year in the middle-of-nowhere Ohio. There‚Äôs not much to do yet my sisters and I were never bored. We would play out in the woods for hours. No matter what we were doing, my grandpa would pause for a moment and then say his favorite catchphrase, ‚ÄúNow girls, this is a gracious living.‚Äù At the time, I was probably either roasting a marshmallow by the fire or getting my fishing line stuck in a tree at the pond and didn‚Äôt think much of it. Now that I‚Äôm all grown up and have the freedom to do anything with my life, I‚Äôve realized that phrase means everything. I want everyday to be a gracious living kind of day. Join Noah and me on our journey as we travel across America and document our gracious living moments where we find ourselves counting our blessings and grateful for the life we‚Äôve been given. This one‚Äôs for you grandpa!  #rvlife #graciousliving #rvliving #rvlifestyle #fulltimerv #gorving #homeonwheels #adventure #travelcouples #homeiswhereyouparkit

This living room was in need of A LOT of help!!! Our clients had waited for their kids to get old enough that this would no longer be the main playroom. They finally decided to move forward. Demo of the fireplace and built-ins started March 9, 2019. The next day, our Governor shut down Ohio to slow the spread of COVID. The room sat with exposed walls and no fireplace for nearly 5 months, waiting for it to be safe to have workers enter their home and be able to select materials. Finally, the fireplace and new built-ins were in!!!! But we had not been able to come in and start designing the furnishings. We begin that phase, more COVID delays, a devastating frost that shut down the entire Country‚Äôs supply of upholstery foam, delays, delays, delays!  Finally, more than a year and a half later this room is complete. Was is worth the wait?  Our clients say, ABSOLUTELY!!!

Things are still not easy. We all have to be patient but it will be worth the wait. 

üì∏ @woven_hearts_photography

The classic Medallion pattern was very popular in the mid 19th century and a number of manufacturers made varying versions of it.
.
New York silversmith John R. Wendt crafted his handsome version in 1862. This lovely set of early American coin silver demitasse spoons showcase his design. They included a hand engraved monogram and are dated for July 4th, 1881 on the back of the handles which make them even more special. Details available by clicking the link in our bio.

Grace with God, grace with others. More on this subject from MM Writer Jasmin in her newest article. Link in the bio. Excerpt below - Sarah

Be gracious with your attitude.

Ephesians 4:2-3 tells us to always be humble and gentle, and to work to maintain peace and unity with one another, especially fellow members of the Body of Christ.

James 1:19-20 is another familiar passage that teaches us to be quick to listen, slow to speak and slow to get angry. Have you read that one before? Sounds a lot different than going on a Twitter rant, cancelling people, and assuming their motives before you even know the full story, doesn‚Äôt it?

Or, how about this? Both the passage in Ephesians 4 and Colossians 3:13 exhort us to make allowance for each other‚Äôs faults because of our love and to forgive anyone who offends us, just as Christ forgave us. Here‚Äôs what that looks like: giving people room to make mistakes and not be perfect (just like you and I make sincere mistakes and aren‚Äôt perfect), being forgiving, and when necessary, helping to restore people back onto the right path with gentleness and humility (Galatians 6:1). All this doesn‚Äôt mean we can‚Äôt ever disagree with anyone or we can‚Äôt have tough conversations, but it does inform the way we go about those conversations and how we live life in general.

What is cervical traction?

Traction of the spine, known as cervical traction, is a popular treatment for neck pain¬†and related injuries. Essentially, cervical traction pulls your head away from your neck to create expansion and eliminate compression. It‚Äôs considered to be an alternative treatment for neck pain, helping people avoid the need for medication or surgeries. It can be used as part of a physical therapy treatment or on your own at home.

Cervical traction devices lightly stretch the neck to reduce pressure on the spine by pulling or separating the vertebrae. It‚Äôs said to be both highly effective and fast-acting. Read on to learn more about this technique and how it can be of benefit to you.

It‚Äôs a sugar cookie kind of day! My grandmother made the BEST sugar cookies - perfectly round (without a cookie cutter) & deliciously crispy! She would bring us dozens, expertly packed in old Crisco containers. Nothing went to waste in her house! I love making these in a vintage mixing bowl & using a Hen House guest towel. Recipe below üëá 

Recipe cred: Val Potts
1 c butter, softened
1 c powdered sugar
1 c granulated sugar
2 large eggs
1 c vegetable oil
2 t. vanilla extract
1 T lemon juice
5 1/4 cups flour
1 t. cream of tartar 
1 t. baking soda
1/4 t. salt

Beat butter until fluffy; add both sugars, beating well.  Add eggs, oil, vanilla & lemon juice, beating until blended.

Combine flour & next 3 ingredients; gradually add to sugar mixture, beating until blended.

Shape dough into 1 inch balls.  Place about 2 inches apart on lightly greased cookie sheets.  Bake at 350 degrees for 9-11 minutes or until set. Do not brown or will be dry.

3 pictures of 3 different smiles because of how accepting and gracious I have learned to be while listening to my body. 

If you are hungry EAT, if you feel even a quench of thirst HYDRATE, if you are sleepy SLEEP. 

It seems like such a simple concept but something that I have struggled with ‚Äúno I‚Äôm not eating that because I‚Äôve already had x amount of calories today‚Äù or ‚Äúmy body is super tired and I‚Äôm mentally exhausted but I NEED to get this workout in‚Äù or ‚ÄúI know I‚Äôm sleepy but I‚Äôm just gonna lay in bed and scroll through my phone a little longer‚Äù. Sometimes ignoring the signs that my body needs fuel or rest. Listening to your body‚Äôs simple requests goes a long way in the end because it‚Äôs telling you exactly what it needs once a routine is placed‚ÄºÔ∏è

UPDATE: SOLD At 13‚Äù, this sterling stuffing spoon was too long to squeeze in the photo.  These spoons were designed with elongated handles to reach inside to retrieve stuffing from the cavity of a bird (pheasant perhaps?)during the Georgian era. This example is Scottish and has hallmarks for sterling, Edinburgh and 1808. Silversmith was Robert Gray and Son. 

Fast forward over 200 years and across the pond to Charleston.  Here a spoon of this type is known as a rice spoon and is sought out by locals and visitors alike. Estate fresh and just arrived @terraceoaksantiques. $420.

I‚Äôve been putting this off for quite some time (because it‚Äôs awkward), but I suppose it‚Äôs time for a formal introduction. I‚Äôm Angela, and I live in Houston (originally a New Yorker) with my husband and two children, James (4) and Eleanor (2).

I‚Äôm a firm believer that you should love where you live. And no, that does not mean having the perfect house ‚Äì mine is full of odd quirks, is not very functional, and quite honestly, was bought out of desperation at the time - I didn‚Äôt even see our house in person before we bought it! I created this space to share ideas and inspiration you can use to create a home and life you are proud to call your own, despite all the imperfections. 

If I could turn back time, I probably would have went to school for interior design. But instead of following my heart and pursing a creative career, I decided to go to law school pretty much on a whim. While my degree may be collecting dust somewhere in this house, it‚Äôs my little reminder that life is way too short to not be doing what brings you joy everyday; and for me, creating, sharing and connecting with all of you is what makes me feel fulfilled. 

So THANK YOU for being here and following along! And if you‚Äôve gotten this far, thank you for reading. üòÇ
